Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Atomic Force Microscope to Enhance Research and Student Research Training in Engineering, Biochemistry, Biology and Physics departments at SF State Univ

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award, funded by the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI), brings new research and teaching capabilities to four Departments/schools at the College of Science and Engineering at San Francisco State University (SFSU) via acquisition of a multipurpose microscope (Bio-AFM). This instrument (Bio-AFM) combines two powerful microscopes: (1) a fluorescence microscope that provides detailed optical images of translucent biological samples, such as cells and soft tissues, and (2) an atomic force microscope (AFM) that provides high-resolution contour maps of samples as well as a broad range of physical properties, such as force, friction, and electric potential. The lack of quantitative techniques in biological sciences has forced researchers to use traditional assessment tools that are typically subjective or not completely quantitative. This instrument will close this gap by empowering development of new quantitative techniques to detect the small effect of medications and medical interventions that occur at the molecular and cellular scales. The techniques will allow researchers to study aging and genetic predisposition by accurately measuring their affects on physical properties of the tissues in micro and nano scales. The instrument will serve as a catalyst for stimulating interdisciplinary collaborations within the college as well as with external users and colleagues at universities, research organizations, and private industries across the Bay Area. The Bio-AFM serves as a critical pedagogical tool in interdepartmental courses designed to offer Masters and undergraduate students hands-on experiences. It will also expand opportunities for recruiting, retaining, and engaging students at a large, urban, comprehensive university with a significant population of individuals who are traditionally under-represented in the disciplines of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Exposure to this state-of-the-art imaging and data acquisition system will augment the training experiences of students and help prepare them for Ph.D. programs or professional careers.

This award promotes a number of new collaborative research projects that will allow in-depth characterization of the mechanical, electrical, and optical properties of natural and engineered materials, as well as imaging of a wide variety of samples, ranging from soft biological tissues to hard metals. The instrument, with its uniquely integrated fluorescence microscope, cutting-edge actuation system, and advanced controls, will ensure the development of open source, quantitative assessment tools that enable any modern AFM to capture the comprehensive micro-mechanics and nano-dynamics of soft biomaterials by finding intrinsic bi-phasic characteristics including elasticity and permeability. Use of the Bio-AFM by SFSU researchers will also enable research advances in the following areas: detecting subtle effects of multiple biological factors such as age and genetic modification on the functions and mechanics of biological materials by using the force indentation tools of the AFM as well as the explained quantitative assessment tool; understanding the impact of different synthesis conditions on the formation and conductivity of polycrystalline thin films under ultraviolet illumination, commonly used in photoelectrochemical applications by using the conductive AFM technique; elucidating the effects of key fabrication parameters on the surface characteristics and mechanical properties of meso-scale materials for energy and filtration applications, by direct mapping and quantification of the surface roughness of electrospun fibers; investigating extracellular organelles synthesized by bacteria and measuring adhesive forces generated by these organelles using the AFM imaging capabilities and the integrated fluorescent microscope; and evaluating the strength of cell-cell interactions by detecting morphological changes and mapping the electrostatic surface potential by using the conductive AFM technique.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF MRI award (Award #1626611) enabled the College of Science & Engineering (CoSE) at San Francisco State University (SFSU) to bring new research and training capacities to the institution through the acquisition of high-resolution instruments called Atomic Force Microscope (AFM). The AFM is a microscope that provides high-resolution images of an object as well as a broad range of physical properties of that object, such as force, friction, and electric potential. This microscope can image extremely small objects such as molecules and DNA that cannot be imaged by any optical microscopes. The awarded AFM is integrated with a fluorescence microscope that can provide synchronized detailed optical images of translucent biological samples, such as cells and soft tissues. These NSF funded instruments were installed in August 2017 in a shared space with the Cell and Molecular Imaging Center (CMIC) (in part funded by NSF MRI DBI 0821204) and the electron microscope in the Electron Microscopy Facility (funded by NSF-MRI CHE-0821619). The awarded AFMs filled a void, as the previous applications were restricted to lower resolution microscopy. As a result, the awarded instruments enabled the creation of a comprehensive microscopy center that supported multidisciplinary research and teaching activities at CoSE.

In particular the awarded instruments supported faculty-sponsored research programs of six faculty members and their student researchers in the School of Engineering, and the Departments of Biology, Chemistry & Biochemistry, and Physics & Astronomy on nano-micro imaging and material characterization. More than 70 faculty members and student-researchers from SFSU and outside users at neighboring universities [the University of California in San Francisco (UCSF) and Berkeley (UCB)] have used these instruments in their research directly and benefited from the awarded instruments. More than fifteen research-students were recruited, trained, and engaged in the research at the forefront of scanning force microscopy by expanding their hands-on research experiences and providing them with access to a leading-edge measurement tool. The instruments fostered collaborative research among the School of Engineering and the participating departments in COSE and UCSF and UCB. Research using awarded instrument has led to thirteen scholarly works so far published by researchers at CoSE.

The investigators developed new training modules and broadly disseminated training materials and course/laboratory modules on the use of the AFM, with an emphasis on micro to atomic-scale imaging and the characterization of materials, including biomaterials, soft tissue, metal oxides, and polymers. More than 60 students received four to eight hours of hands-on training in their undergraduate courses to perform experiments, collect data, and analyze data using the awarded instruments. The acquisition of the AFM supported CoSE?s mission to provide hands-on and meaningful research experiences to its diverse student body of undergraduate and master?s students and to prepare them for advanced degrees and successful careers. Training on state-of-the-art research equipment gave our students a leading-edge when applying for positions in the industrial sector or to Ph.D. programs.

In addition to research and training activities, we used these instruments to inspire and excite high school students in pursuing science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors. So far, we have held nine outreach events for enthusiastic high-school students in neighboring schools who are hopefully our future scientists and engineers. We have held at least one open house every year so far to introduce the facility to the public and students. To promote the facility, we regularly invited researchers from other universities who are in the vicinity of the SFSU to come and tour the facility. The awarded instruments will continue to benefit research and teaching at SFSU and we are grateful to taxpayers who truly fund these useful awards and NSF. The principal investigator as a proud Iranian who proudly supports his students at an American institute hopes that the research and training outcomes of this award will benefit all people around the world and bring them closer to one other.
